title: Bengals won't make fans happy in top 10 NFL mock draft
description: The Bengals get a top prospect in a new mock draft. But it'll give fans some sour deja vu.
fullText:
The Cincinnati Bengals will almost certainly, once again, be on the lookout for help in the defensive secondary.

Don‚Äôt be surprised if the Bengals take yet another stab at finding a cornerstone cornerback in the draft after a number of misses in recent years.

A recent mock draft from Sports Illustrated‚Äôs Daniel Flick has the Bengals tapping into Joe Burrow‚Äôs alma mater of LSU to grab cornerback Mansoor Delane.

The Bengals have the NFL‚Äôs worst defense, ranking last in total yards, scoring and rushing yards allowed and No. 29 in passing yards allowed. Delane is the draft‚Äôs best cornerback, and his elite instincts and route anticipation enable him to thrive in both man and zone coverages. The 6' 0", 190-pound Delane has above-average ball skills, with two interceptions and 11 pass breakups this season, and is a physical, willing tackler in run support. He‚Äôs the complete package and should start as a rookie.

Delane was a unanimous All-American and First-Team All-SEC in 2025. He recorded 45 tackles and two interceptions this season and just recently officially declared for the draft.

The Bengals have DJ Turner and Dax Hill as long-term options. But the Cam Taylor-Britt experiment is over and the search for higher-end prospects will start once again.

This article originally appeared on Bengals Wire: Bengals won't make fans happy in top 10 NFL mock draft

title: NFL power rankings Week 17: Top teams tumble, new No. 1, how bad are the Cowboys?
description: The Cowboys keep losing, but the fight at the top is ridiculously crowded with just two weeks left in the season. Who is the best?
fullText:
This might be the most top-heavy season in recent NFL memory. Following Sunday's games in Week 16, there are now eight teams within one game of having the league's best record, and the San Francisco 49ers could make it nine by Monday night's end. The two teams sitting atop last week's rankings both lost, with the Denver Broncos losing by 14 points at home after standing alone as the best record.

Things are shaping up for an incredible playoff season and with two weeks remaining, seeds are more up for grabs than ever. Meanwhile, if the top if heavy, the bottom is as well. There are seven teams with four wins or fewer, stinking up the joint each and every week. The battle for the No. 1 draft pick is just as intense as that for the No. 1 seeds. Here's a look at our latest Power Rankings.

title: Who in the world wants to watch Grandpa Philip Rivers? Answer: Everyone
description: At 8-6, the Colts are on the outside looking in at the playoff picture, but 44-year-old Philip Rivers coming in off the couch is one of the great stories of this NFL season.
fullText:
Just think, for a moment, how you‚Äôd look in a pair of form-fitting football pants and a tight-around-the-belly jersey. Would you look like a honed specimen of humanity, lean and taut and ready to explode? Or would you look like 10 pounds of sausage in a five-pound casing, busting the seams?

If you‚Äôre being honest, you, me, and pretty much everyone both of us knows would look a whole lot more like a sausage than a specimen. A whole lot like Philip Rivers does, honestly.

But the difference between Philip Rivers and us, of course, is that we aren‚Äôt starting at quarterback on Monday Night Football.

Rivers and the briefly-mighty, now-floundering Indianapolis Colts take on the San Francisco 49ers in a matchup that, from a sheer talent standpoint, looked a whole lot more attractive back in September than it does now. Ball-knowers will scoff at Rivers and wonder who in the world would want to watch a 44-year-old grandfather run around for three hours.

To which I would say: Everyone. Everyone would love to see that. Because what Rivers is doing is both awesome and ridiculous.

In any other career, Rivers would be hitting his prime at age 44, old enough to have learned the ropes but young enough to have the energy and desire to do more. In sports, though, he‚Äôs impossibly ancient, a relic who could burst into a pile of dust with one good sack. Hopefully he won‚Äôt, but that‚Äôs the line on most aged pro athletes.

Players like Tom Brady and LeBron James have redefined the possible parameters of a late-career athlete, but then again, Tom Brady and LeBron James are arguably the GOATs of their respective sports. They played for such a high level for so long that their age-related decline merely brought them down to star level.

Rivers wasn‚Äôt ever in that stratosphere, though he had a few years in the mid-2000s ‚Äî you know, about two decades ago ‚Äî when he garnered some Pro Bowl nods and MVP votes. He ran with all the speed of the changing seasons, yes, but he also possessed two valuable attributes ‚Äî an orbital-launch arm and a surpassing knowledge of potential defensive schemes.

That‚Äôs how he was able to come back and mesh with the Colts so quickly last week against Seattle. He played within himself, tossing a nifty 18 of 27 completions for 160 yards, with a long of just 17 yards. He had an adjusted yards gained per pass attempt of 3.52 ‚Äî quite the falloff from the 8- to 9-yard average of his best days. Against San Francisco, he could fare even better; the 49ers trail Seattle in every major defensive category.

But stats are for nerds. What Grandpa Rivers did last week was ball, plain and simple. And now he‚Äôs getting a chance to take Indy on a last-ditch playoff run? Come on, how can you not love this?

At 8-6, Indianapolis sits in the dreaded first-team-out spot, well behind 10-5 division rival Houston for the final spot in the AFC playoffs. After this week, the Colts have games against the Texans and Jaguars, both teams they‚Äôre staring up at in the playoff bracket. The Athletic gives Indianapolis just a 3 percent chance of making the playoffs, which is a rough prognosis given the Colts‚Äô 7-1 start to 2025.

That‚Äôs tough news for the franchise and the city, but on a micro level, a great story is unfolding. Rivers is the embodiment of every former football player ‚Äî whether high school, college or just two-hand touch Turkey Bowl ‚Äî who would love to get one more turn in the arena, one more play with the ball in their hands, one more chance to rear back and throw it deep. He‚Äôs living the dream that if you keep in shape, if you keep your edge ‚Äî if not your waistline ‚Äî then maybe, just maybe, they‚Äôll call your number one more time. Father Time is undefeated, yes, but you can always move the ball against him if you want it badly enough.

Rivers‚Äô return is a hell of a story, however it ends. But it‚Äôd be nice if he went out with at least one more victory. Why not a prime-time one?

description: Trevor Lawrence earns a statement win for the Jaguars in NFL week 16, but Detroit and Baltimore are in big trouble - and Caleb Williams has found his ideal coach in Chicago.
fullText:
Wild finishes, big comebacks, upsets, big-name injuries and play-off places decided - just another week in the NFL.

Aaron Rodgers described the end of Pittsburgh's win in Detroit as "chaos" and that pretty much summed up week 16.

Five teams punched their play-off tickets, with the New England Patriots beating the Baltimore Ravens to join the Seattle Seahawks, San Francisco 49ers, Philadelphia Eagles and Chicago Bears in the post-season.

Jacksonville are on the verge of joining them after the performance of the day on Sunday, but what else caught the eye this week?

title: NFL Playoff picture: Week 16 shakes up the AFC and NFC standings
description: Week 16 reshaped the NFL playoff picture. Here is where things stand ahead of Colts-49ers
fullText:
Week 16 saw several teams clinch playoff spots, and changed the pecking order in both the NFC and the AFC.

In the NFC, we have a new team in the No. 1 spot, and just two playoff spots left up for grabs as five teams have now clinched.

In the AFC, the race for the No. 1 spot remains tight, as six teams remain alive in the chase for the bye week.

Here is the full state of play in the NFC ahead of Monday Night Football:

Philadelphia Eagles (10-5) ‚Äì xy

Washington Commanders (4-11) ‚Äì e

x ‚Äì Team has clinched a playoff spot
y ‚Äì Team has clinched their division
e ‚Äì Team has been eliminated from playoff contention

Thanks to Sunday‚Äôs action, only two playoff spots are left up for grabs in the NFC.

Let‚Äôs start at the top of the conference. Seattle‚Äôs huge overtime win over the Los Angeles Rams not only punched the Seahawks‚Äô ticket for the playoffs, but it put them in the driver‚Äôs seat for the No. 1 seed in the conference. Seattle now controls their destiny in the chase for the top spot, as wins in their final two games (over Carolina and San Francisco) would give them the No. 1 seed.

The Philadelphia Eagles became the first team to clinch their division, as they wrapped up the NFC East with their win over the Washington Commanders on Saturday night. Philadelphia also became the first team to win the NFC East in back-to-back seasons since ‚Ä¶ the Eagles accomplished that feat back in 2004.

Speaking of the Panthers, Carolina moved into a playoff spot with their win over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. If the postseason began today the Panthers would be in as the No. 4 seed. Tampa Bay‚Äôs loss dropped them out of the playoffs, and behind the Minnesota Vikings in the standings. The two teams have matching 7-8 records, but the Vikings have a better conference record.

Tampa Bay can still win the division, however, as they play Carolina in Week 18.

Chicago‚Äôs win over the Packers moved the Bears one step closer to an NFC North title, while putting Green Bay‚Äôs playoff chances onto shakier ground. Still, with the Lions losing to the Steelers on Sunday afternoon, the Packers still have some breathing room.

Chicago also clinched a playoff spot with the Lions‚Äô loss, as did the 49ers.

Here is what the NFC Wild Card matchups woulkd look like if the playoffs started today:

No. 7 Green Bay at No. 2 Chicago

No 6 San Francisco at No. 3 Philadelphia

No. 5 Los Angeles at No. 4 Carolina

Seattle would have the No. 1 seed and the bye week.

Here is the state of play in the AFC:

New England Patriots (12-3) ‚Äì x

Let‚Äôs start at the bottom of the playoff teams. Houston‚Äôs win over the Raiders gives the Texans a two-game lead over Indianapolis in the win column, ahead of the Colts‚Äô game tonight against the San Francisco 49ers.

The Los Angeles Chargers and the Buffalo Bills have matching 11-4 records, but the Chargers have a better AFC record (8-2 vs. 8-3) than the Bills, so the Chargers slot into the No. 5 slot while the Bills settle for No. 6. Los Angeles has two more AFC games remaining (Houston and Denver) while the Bills just have the Jets remaining on their list of AFC opponents.

Denver‚Äôs loss to Jacksonville, coupled with New England‚Äôs win over the Baltimore Ravens, tightened things at the top of the AFC as both teams have matching 12-3 records. The Broncos remain in the top spot due to a better record in common games (6-0 versus 4-1), and Denver has clinched that tiebreaker. However, in addition to the Patriots and Broncos, the Jaguars, Chargers, Bills, and Texans are all alive in the chase for the No. 1 pick.

Here is what the AFC playoffs would look like if they began today, with Denver having the bye week:

No. 7 Houston at No. 2 New England

No. 6 Buffalo at No. 3 Jacksonville

No. 5 Los Angeles at No. 4 Pittsburgh

There are going to be some new fans around the league rooting for the 49ers tonight.

First, let‚Äôs start with what this game means for the teams playing on Monday Night Football. The 49ers clinched a playoff spot when the Lions lost to the Steelers, and are now jockeying for position in the NFC pecking order. If the 49ers defeat the Colts, they will improve to 11-4, tying them with the Los Angeles Rams. But the 49ers would move into the No. 5 spot and drop the Rams down to the No. 6 spot, thanks to San Francisco‚Äôs better division record. San Francisco is 4-1 in NFC West games, while the Rams are 3-2.

It is worth noting that the Seahawks are 3-2 in NFC West games as well, and they play San Francisco in Week 18 having already lost to the 49ers back in Week 1.

If the 49ers lose, they will remain in the No. 6 slot.

As for the Colts, they enter Monday Night Football on the outside looking in. A win would not move Indianapolis into a playoff spot, but they would close to within one game of the Texans for the No. 7 spot.

But if the Colts lose, they will be eliminated from AFC South title contention, and they would drop two games behind the Texans in the race for a playoff spot with two games remaining.

In addition, if the Colts lose, the Chargers, Bills, and Jaguars all clinch playoff spots.

title: NFL playoff picture update: Detroit Lions‚Äô hopes are essentially dead
description: A look at the NFC playoff picture and the Detroit Lions‚Äô dwindling postseason odds and clinching scenarios.
fullText:
With a devastating loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers, the Detroit Lions have dropped to 8-7 on the season, and their playoff hopes are about as realistic as Calvin Johnson coming out of retirement. Here‚Äôs a look at what the playoff picture looks like, the Lions‚Äô remaining playoff scenarios, and where the rest of the division and conference looks like.

The Lions can no longer win the NFC North, and the Bears are just a single win away from clinching their first division title since 2018. It‚Äôs a tough pill to swallow for Lions fans, as it appears Ben Johnson was the perfect hire for the Bears.

The Lions are actually in danger of falling into fourth place in the NFC North, and a loss to the Vikings on Christmas would nearly seal it. Both teams would be 8-8, the Vikings would finish with a season sweep of the Lions, and Detroit would finish the season with a tough matchup against a Bears team that may be still looking to clinch the division.

Of course, maybe it would be a blessing in disguise for the Lions to finish last in the division so that they could play a fourth-place schedule next year (which would like feature games against the Giants, Titans, and Cardinals).

Wild Card race (top three advance)

The Lions‚Äô best potential record is 10-7, meaning they can only mathematically catch the 49ers and Packers. But because the 49ers have locked in the tiebreaker over the Lions due to their conference record (8-2 vs. 5-5), the Packers are the only team Detroit can actually catch.

Obviously that would require the Lions to win both of their remaining games (at Vikings, at Bears), but the Packers would also have to lose out. Green Bay has the 7-8 Baltimore Ravens this upcoming week, who lost Lamar Jackson to a back injury on Sunday night. And they finish out with the Vikings, who lost J.J. McCarthy to a throwing hand injury on Sunday. Even though the Packers are struggling and have a bunch of injuries of their own, that seems very unlikely to happen.

The New York Times only gives the Lions a 6% chance to make the playoffs. NextGenStats has Detroit at 8%.

title: WWE Superstar Seth Rollins discusses Netflix's NFL Christmas Gameday
description: During his chat with @EdEastonJr, WWE Superstar Seth Rollins discussed Netflix's NFL Christmas Gameday doubleheader
fullText:
This week, Chiefs Wire's Ed Easton Jr. spoke with WWE Superstar and long-time Chicago Bears fan Seth Rollins.

In his interview with Easton Jr., Rollins discussed his role as a special guest for NFL Christmas Gameday on Netflix on Thursday, December 25th. He will be in attendance for the Detroit Lions at the Minnesota Vikings, providing insight on the NFC North rivals.

"Well, my hope at that point is that the Bears have locked up a spot in the playoffs, and I don't have to stress. However, they have a hell of a schedule coming up. They got Green Bay and San Francisco, then finished with Detroit," said Rollins, "So for one night only, I will be a Minnesota Vikings fan. Don't tell anybody from Detroit. But yeah, I'm going to be rooting for the Vikings. I'm probably going to need them to take the Lions down a peg so that the Bears can lock in and get it done. But yeah, it should be a fun game."

The streaming service returns on Christmas Day with another NFL global doubleheader, following the Kansas City Chiefs' victory in last year's first-ever broadcast over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Get ready for some action-packed Christmas magic üéÑ 

Dallas Cowboys vs. Washington Commanders at 1 PM ET 
Detroit Lions vs. Minnesota Vikings at 4:30 PM ET 

LIVE on Netflix December 25 pic.twitter.com/pVUKmqtrCM

‚Äî Netflix Sports (@netflixsports) December 3, 2025

The Vikings will rely on 2024 first-round draft pick J.J. McCarthy, who has been inconsistent due to injuries, while the Lions try to regain the dominant form that propelled them last season.

"Curious to see the progression of J.J. McCarthy and what he looks like in Kevin O'Connell's offense as he goes through sort of what his rookie year is. Obviously, he missed last season with the injury, but it's kind of his first go-around," said Rollins, "Which Lions are we going to get? Lions from last year that dominated and maybe made an early playoff exit, or are we going to get a Lions team that misses the playoffs this season? It's going to be very interesting to see. Looking forward to the matchup, and yeah, I will be saying 'Skol' all afternoon."

Netflix's inaugural NFL Christmas games in 2024 smashed streaming records, with the Chiefs vs. Steelers game averaging over 24 million U.S. viewers and reaching nearly 65 million unique viewers across the doubleheader, making it the most-streamed NFL games ever on the platform.

Rollins will star in WWE Unreal Season 2, premiering on January 20, 2026: https://www.netflix.com/tudum/articles/wwe-unreal-season-2-release-date-trailer-news.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: WWE Superstar Seth Rollins discusses Netflix's NFL Christmas Gameday

title: Browns NFL Draft order 2026: Where Cleveland stands after Week 16
description: The Cleveland Browns have all but control their own destiny in the 2026 NFL draft order with a top 2 pick likely
fullText:
The Cleveland Browns head into the final two weeks of the 2025 NFL season with a clear chance to clinch one of the first two picks in the 2026 NFL draft. The Browns moved up to the third spot after the early Week 16 games on Sunday, but saw the Las Vegas Raiders fail to knock off the Houston Texans in a very close game that would have helped Cleveland move up even further.

The Browns close loss to the Buffalo Bills was made much worse by the significant injuries to RB Quinshon Judkins. While there was a positive estimate after the game, Cleveland fans await confirmation on whether Judkins‚Äô ligaments are intact.

With just one game left in Week 16, the Browns remain locked into the third spot in the 2026 NFL draft order, with the pick they acquired from the Jacksonville Jaguars likely awaiting the results in the NFL playoffs.

Los Angeles Rams (via Atlanta Falcons)

New York Jets (via Indianapolis Colts)

Dallas Cowboys (via Green Bay Packers)

Cleveland Browns (via Jacksonville Jaguars)

The Giants and Raiders play each other next week, with Las Vegas also set to play the (zombie) Chiefs in Week 18. The Browns seem destined to pick in the top two in the 2026 NFL draft at this point, as long as they lose their final two games.

title: Taysom Hill‚Äôs potentially last home game with Saints ended with another history-making effort
description: The 9-year NFL veteran provided a major spark for New Orleans in its win over the Jets.
fullText:
Taysom Hill has made a name for himself as a do-everything asset in the New Orleans Saints‚Äô toolbox over the past nine seasons.

If Sunday night ends up being his final home game with the NFL franchise, he left the home confines of Caesars Superdome by making history yet again.

The former BYU quarterback made contributions as a runner, receiver and passer in the Saints‚Äô 29-6 over the New York Jets on Sunday.

That included running for a team-high 42 yards on 12 carries, finishing with four catches for 36 yards ‚Äî he is listed as a tight end nowadays, after all ‚Äî and completed his only pass attempt for a 38-yard touchdown pass to Chris Olave to cap the victory.

Cinema. 

üì∫ CBS pic.twitter.com/nggfuDSBnx

‚Äî New Orleans Saints (@Saints) December 21, 2025

With his 36 receiving yards, Hill ‚Äî who‚Äôs played multiple positions on offense and been a special teams ace during his time in New Orleans ‚Äî moved past 1,000 career receiving yards.

Hill now has 2,388 passing yards, 2,545 rushing yards and 1,002 receiving yards in his career.

After today's performance, Taysom Hill now has 2,388 passing yards, 2,545 rushing yards, and 1,002 career receiving yards. With his 36 receiving yards today, Hill is now the only player with over 1,000 yards passing, rushing, and receiving in the @NFL Super Bowl era. pic.twitter.com/FxMhfY2qaL

‚Äî New Orleans Saints PR (@SaintsPR) December 21, 2025

The 35-year-old Hill, who‚Äôs in the final year of a four-year contract extension that includes voidable years in 2026 and 2027, became emotional when he reflected on his time in New Orleans after the win.

‚ÄúAs I was driving to the stadium today, you start to think about the last nine years and what it has meant to me and my family,‚Äù he told reporters postgame, per the team website.

‚ÄúI think for me, you just try to take it all in. It‚Äôs been a great experience here today and I don‚Äôt know what the future holds for me, but it was a special day for me and my family.‚Äù

.@T_Hill4 on the past 9 years in New Orleans and what this city means to him pic.twitter.com/xSyUa2O99c

‚Äî New Orleans Saints (@Saints) December 21, 2025

Hill restructured his contract last offseason, and there are no contractual ties to keep him in New Orleans beyond 2025. He started the year on the PUP list after having his 2024 campaign cut short by a significant knee injury that included a torn ACL, and it makes sense for a rebuilding Saints team to move in another direction.

‚ÄúI can tell you, I have so much love for the city of New Orleans and this fan base and the way that they‚Äôve embraced me and my family,‚Äù Hill said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been really special. I wouldn‚Äôt want to play somewhere else, but there‚Äôs a lot of circumstances that are out of your control and I understand the nature of this business. I‚Äôm not thinking that way right now, but we‚Äôll tackle that when we get there.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis league talks about trying to find ‚ÄòTaysom Hills,‚Äô but no one can duplicate it.‚Äù

New Orleans Saints coach Kellen Moore

New Orleans first-year coach Kellen Moore, who is Hill‚Äôs third head coach in his time with the Saints, shared what Hill has meant to the franchise.

‚ÄúThis league talks about trying to find ‚ÄòTaysom Hills,‚Äô but no one can duplicate it,‚Äù Moore said. ‚ÄúHis ability to play every phase of the offense and contribute on special teams is really special.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs an A-plus person, an A-plus human being and an A-plus player. Our young guys can learn a lot from him.‚Äù

#Saints HC Kellen Moore on Taysom Hill:

"This league talks about trying to get Taysom Hills on your football team ... no one seems to be able to duplicate it." pic.twitter.com/JtZkkQWbVr

‚Äî NOF (@nofnetwork) December 21, 2025

In Sunday‚Äôs game, Hill delivered an effort that was vintage Swiss Army Knife.

He led New Orleans in rushing, made plays from his tight end position and even threw a touchdown with under two minutes to play.

That score was something the Saints acknowledged they were trying to get for Hill, in case he doesn‚Äôt return.

When he heard the team was trying to get Hill a touchdown, Olave made sure he was on the field at a point in the game when he didn‚Äôt need to be in the contest risking injury.

‚ÄúDefinitely wanted to be a part of that, especially knowing they wanted to get Taysom a touchdown, so I wanted to be a part of that ‚Äî a deep ball, too ‚Äî so I definitely wanted to be in there,‚Äù Olave said.

title: Who plays on 'Monday Night Football' tonight? Time, TV channel, schedule, live stream for NFL Week 16 game

title: NFL power rankings: Seahawks edge Patriots for new No. 1; Jaguars, Bears also rise; Packers fade for Week 17
description: How do all 32 teams in the NFL stack up against each other coming out of Week 16 of the 2025 NFL regular season? Here's an updated look from best to worst.
fullText:
NFL power rankings: Seahawks edge Patriots for new No. 1; Jaguars, Bears also rise; Packers fade for Week 17 originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Ranking all 32 teams in the NFL from best to worst for every week in the 2025 regular season has been a wild ride. With such a top-heavy league, the hierarchy can see a big change based on a few particular results.

That has often caused teams to jump high or fade fast in relation to the others near the top. Even the back end has seen some significant reshuffling of late.

Here's Sporting News' latest breakdown from the tippy top to rock bottom coming out of Week 16:

MORE:¬†Updated AFC, NFC playoff picture after Week 16 results

The Seahawks¬†won that thriller over the Rams with the offense rebounding after a slow passing start. They need Sam Darnold to cut down on the mistakes and keep raising the big plays to live up to their lofty playoff position.

The Patriots¬†went into more of an offensive slump in Baltimore with Drake Maye cooling and being contained again, putting their chances of stealing the AFC East in serious jeopardy.

MORE:¬†Patriots clinch playoff spot for first time since 2021

The Rams¬†had no problems moving the ball without Davante Adams with Matthew Stafford spreading the ball around and getting more from the running game. But the secondary issues in Seattle became more prevalent when the front cannot get pressure.

The Broncos¬†couldn't find enough clean offense from Bo Nix to make another fourth-quarter comeback in what looked more like a blowout loss to the Jaguars. Their defense, having key lapses, is a shaky late development.

The Jaguars¬†had their true statement victory in Denver, making six straight wins. Their road domination and finishing well in the fourth quarter bodes well for their playoff profile.

MORE: 6 reasons why Jaguars are legitimate Super Bowl contenders

The Bears¬†should be thrilled to have the late-game comeback mode of Caleb Williams, always giving them a chance. Chicago is pushing toward being a tough out in the playoffs.

MORE:¬†Bears take control of NFC North with win over Packers

The Bills¬†were caught in a tough battle down the road in Cleveland as Josh Allen's clunker against a tough defense was saved by James Cook and the running game. The defense was fortunate to face a team with limited weapons to survive

The Chargers¬†went into Dallas and used it for a get-well offensive game with more juice from their defense, too. Justin Herbert needed that and so did Jim Harbaugh.

The 49ers¬†should have loved the fact that the Seahawks took down the Rams on Thursday night. Their offense is red-hot and a win over the Colts would give them control of the division in the final two weeks.

The Eagles¬†have got their offensive groove back with Saquon Barkley running well and Jalen Hurts' passing efficiently everywhere to silence the critics. They don't need to worry about the division anymore and can focus on getting into top shape for their Super Bowl defense in the playoffs.

The¬†Packers¬†saw Jordan Love get concussed in Chicago with Malik Willis playing well enough to win, but had too many offensive, defensive and special teams lapses to create a bigger mess than injuries.

The Texans¬†were able to hold off the Raiders with resilient offense and just enough of their trademark defense. The hiccup is excusable with a win, but much must be fixed before facing the Chargers next week.

MORE:¬†Texans keep playoff hopes alive by escaping with win over Raiders

The Steelers¬†found their running game again in Detroit to balance out the stellar run defense. They keep getting better at the right time to get into the playoffs on an uptick with Aaron Rodgers.

The Lions¬†have been struggling to run the ball at will like they did last season and taking that element away, as the Steelers did. That and an injury-depleted defense have been the downfall for Detroit as a playoff contender.

The Panthers¬†showed a lot of moxie in outlasting the Buccaneers with Bryce Young winning the biggest passing duel of his career. They have a great shot at making some noise should they get into the NFC playoffs.

MORE:¬†Panthers take control of NFC South with massive win over Buccaneers

The¬†Colts¬†will try to do more with a game Philip Rivers on Monday night against the 49ers with their season on the line, but the defense also may not oblige in a tough spot.

The Ravens¬†had another defensive meltdown and other fourth-quarter big mistakes to blow another big lead, this time vs. the Patriots, spelling doom for a bad overall season, now maybe with Lamar Jackson not finishing healthy.

MORE:¬†Ravens' path to the postseason gets bleaker with loss to Patriots

The Buccaneers¬†are making too many mistakes late in games, from the defense to Baker Mayfield. They can still get into the playoffs but there will be less inspiration for them to last long against a tough wild-card draw.

The¬†Vikings¬†can't seem to keep J.J. McCarthy healthy right when he builds positive momentum, but they still grounded out another win with enough clutch plays and more needed tough defense against what was a promising Giants offense.

The Cowboys¬†look like they're running out of gas offensively to keep trying to make up for historically horrible all-around defense. This disappointment can't be blamed on Dak Prescott.

The¬†Falcons¬†are working to finish strong with wins over the Buccaneers and Cardinals making them feel better about the future of Raheem Morris as head coach. Credit Morris for getting them to be inspired with nothing left on the line.

The Chiefs¬†can't be expected to win with their defense not having a pass rush and their offense not having a passing game minus Patrick Mahomes, Gardner Minshew and their top wide receiver. The fact they lost so easily on the road to the Titans is just so shocking.

MORE:¬†How Travis Kelce's retirement decision is easy with no Patrick Mahomes

The Saints¬†took care of the lesser Jets at home with Tyler Shough chucking well with help from diverse weapons under Kellen Moore. He should go into Year 2 as the starting QB and the defense is also playing with a lot of late conviction.

The¬†Bengals¬†showed almost no life in Week 15 against the Ravens but got up off the mat to rip an overmatched and lesser-motivated Dolphins team with Joe Burrow needing that get-well performance late to try to end the season on a positive.

The Dolphins¬†have faded fast from their rally back into playoff contention with dismal performances against the Steelers and Bengals in consecutive losses. Mike McDaniel can feel the heat again with the Tua Tagovailoa benching backfiring.

The Commanders¬†just haven't fielded enough reliable defense all season long, with their age and youth showing in all the wrong places. They will just hope everything will change again with a healthy Jayden Daniels leading the offense.

The Titans¬†are seeing a much-improved Cam Ward in recent weeks and it added up to a nice confidence-building win against the reeling Chiefs at home.

The Browns¬†fought hard against the Bills with Shedeur Sanders showing the kind of fight and play that gets him a full-season audition as the starter in 2026 despite the defense falling apart around Myles Garrett.

MORE:¬†Myles Garrett inches closer to NFL sack record with obscure half sack

The Cardinals' positive offensive vibes have hit a wall with Jacoby Brissett and the rest of their backups, who have had too much pressure to compensate for a Jonathan Gannon potential lame-duck defense.

The Jets¬†did their best to stay competitive with Brady Cook starting again at quarterback but the bigger problem is Aaron Glenn's shell of an overall defense. They are a really lost, bad team.

MORE:¬†Updated NFL draft order after Week 16

Jaxson Dart was due for a clunker and the Vikings' defense delivered it to him. The lumps have been there enough to go forward with a new coaching system all-around.

The¬†Raiders¬†showed more life with their offense in of all places, Houston against the Texans' nasty defense. They also played their most inspired defensive game in weeks. It still wasn't enough to overcome their lack of execution.

title: Texans playoff picture: Updated chances for Houston to make 2025 NFL postseason after Week 16 win over Raiders
description: The Texans are moving closer to a playoff return.
fullText:
Texans playoff picture: Updated chances for Houston to make 2025 NFL postseason after Week 16 win over Raiders originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Houston Texans don't always make it look pretty, but that's par for the course for a team driven by its defense.

After falling behind in the second half of Sunday's game against the Las Vegas Raiders, the Texans held on and won for the 10th time in their last 12 games after starting the season 0-3.

A seven-game win streak has the Texans dreaming of a deep playoff run, but have they clinched their spot in the postseason yet?

Here's what you need to know about the Texans' playoff chances and how they can punch their ticket.

How Travis Kelce's retirement decision is easy with no Patrick Mahomes

Panthers take control of NFC South with massive win over Buccaneers

Myles Garrett inches closer to NFL sack record with obscure half sack

Gardner Minshew suffers potential ACL tear in first Chiefs game without Patrick Mahomes

Quinshon Judkins out for season after gruesome leg injury vs. Bills

The Texans couldn't catch the Jacksonville Jaguars in the AFC South on Sunday with Jacksonville winning in Denver, but Houston's win ensures the race will remain a tight one entering the final two weeks of the season.

The Indianapolis Colts would be eliminated from AFC South contention with a loss to the San Francisco 49ers on Monday.

The Texans cannot clinch a playoff berth in Week 16, but the victory did bring them one major step closer to punching their ticket.

A Colts loss on Monday would make Houston's path to clinching in Week 17 much simpler, but the Texans are in control of their fate when it comes to getting into the playoffs.

Elsewhere, Sunday's results were not ideal for the Texans. Houston missed an opportunity to jump higher than the No. 7 seed because the Los Angeles Chargers and Buffalo Bills both won and the Jaguars maintained their lead in the AFC South.

Watch DK Metcalf throw punch at Lions fan on sidelines

Kenneth Gainwell makes circus catch for potential coach of the year

The Texans have a tough test against the Chargers in Week 17, going out to the West Coast to play a critical Saturday game against a likely playoff team.

Houston closes its season against the Colts, though it's unclear whether Indianapolis will still be in playoff contention by Week 18.

title: Patriots game day roster: NFL Week 16 vs. Ravens
description: A look at the Patriots‚Äô game day roster for their Week 16 game on Sunday night.
fullText:
With Robert Spillane sidelined throughout the game, the New England Patriots‚Äô linebacker group had a disappointing outing last week versus the Buffalo Bills. The challenge will not be any easier for the position on Sunday night against the Baltimore Ravens.

Not only will Spillane miss a second straight game because of an ankle injury, the Ravens feature one of the best run games in the NFL. Led by the two-headed monster of quarterback Lamar Jackson and running back Derrick Henry, they are entering Sunday as the league leaders in yards per carry (5.2).

With Spillane out, that means the task on stopping this potent an attack will fall on replacement starting duo Jack Gibbens and Christian Elliss. As head coach Mike Vrabel pointed out on Friday, however, they will not be the only one in the spotlight.

‚ÄúEverybody that goes to the game is going to play and have a role, and we ask everybody to prepare as starters,‚Äù Vrabel explained. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs something that‚Äôs important. And so, Gibby will start in there, and then different guys will play, packages and everything else.‚Äù

New England‚Äôs full game day roster against the Ravens looks as follows:

Quarterback (2):¬†Drake Maye (10), Joshua Dobbs (11)

Running back (4):¬†Rhamondre Stevenson (38), TreVeyon Henderson (32), D‚ÄôErnest Johnson (34), Jack Westover (37 | FB/TE)

Wide receiver (5):¬†Kayshon Boutte (9), Stefon Diggs (8), Mack Hollins (13), DeMario Douglas (3), Kyle Williams (18 | KR)

The Patriots‚Äô front seven is seeing some changes compared to last week. Not only is Chad Muma active as extra depth at linebacker and on special teams just five days after getting claimed off waivers from the Indianapolis Colts, two recent inactives are also up this week: Eric Gregory will provide additional depth at defensive tackle, while Bradyn Swinson should help on the edge.

Swinson‚Äôs presence on the game day roster comes in light of starter Harold Landry being questionable with a knee injury. The fifth-round rookie has appeared in one game so far, playing 10 snaps in the kicking game but none on defense.

Practice squad/exempt (1):¬†TE Thomas Odukoya (88 | IPPP)

Reserve/retired (1):¬†OL Wes Schweitzer

With no players elevated from the practice squad, a total of five players were ruled out on Sunday. The list includes no surprises, with Spillane, who was deemed inactive ahead of the weekend already, as the only noteworthy absence.

The Patriots‚Äô game against the Ravens will kick off at 8:20 p.m. ET at M&T Bank Stadium in Baltimore.

title: Panthers rookie Lathan Ransom goes from goat to hero in one week after game-clinching interception
description: Carolina Panthers rookie safety Lathan Ransom has experienced the dramatic highs and lows of playing in the NFL in his first season.  One week after a crucial penalty that led to a costly loss to the New Orleans Saints, Ransom redeemed himself on Sunday by intercepting Baker Mayfield with 42 seconds left to seal the Panthers' 23-20 win over the Buccaneers ‚Äî allowing Carolina to vault into sole possession of first place in the NFC South.  Ransom couldn't have felt much worse last week on the flight home from New Orleans after he was flagged for hitting sliding Saints quarterback Tyler Shough with 9 seconds left on a bang-bang play.
fullText:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) ‚Äî Carolina Panthers rookie safety Lathan Ransom has experienced the dramatic highs and lows of playing in the NFL in his first season.

One week after a crucial penalty that led to a costly loss to the New Orleans Saints, Ransom redeemed himself on Sunday by intercepting Baker Mayfield with 42 seconds left to seal the Panthers' 23-20 win over the Buccaneers ‚Äî allowing Carolina to vault into sole possession of first place in the NFC South.

‚ÄúI faced a lot of adversity, and I heard noise from everybody last week,‚Äù Ransom said. ‚Äú... (But) that‚Äôs how you shake back.‚Äù

Ransom couldn't have felt much worse last week on the flight home from New Orleans after he was flagged for hitting sliding Saints quarterback Tyler Shough with 9 seconds left on a bang-bang play. Officials flagged Ransom for unnecessary roughness, and the 15-yard penalty turned a difficult 61-yard field goal attempt into a far more makable one from 46 yards.

Charlie Smyth put it through the uprights to complete the Saints' 20-17 come-from-behind win.

Had the Panthers defeated the Saints, they would have only needed to beat the Bucs on Sunday to clinch the NFC South and end a seven-year playoff drought. Instead, the loss left the Panthers on the outside of the playoff bubble.

Ransom said he was hard on himself.

But the fourth-draft pick from Ohio State decided early last week that instead of dwelling on the mistake he'd use it as motivation.

‚ÄúI understand that the game is not won or lost by one play, but people behind their phone are going to have their own opinions,‚Äù Ransom said. ‚ÄúI just heard all the noise ‚Äî listened to it and used it as fuel for this game.‚Äù

Ransom leaned on the support last week of veteran defensive leaders such as Jaycee Horn, Derrick Brown and Mike Jackson, who shares the locker next to him.

Jackson and others advised to look ahead, not back and keeping playing at full speed.

‚ÄúHe responded like a grown man should," Jackson said. ‚ÄúAt the end of day, everyone was talking trash to him, like he shouldn't be in the game and this and that. And today he responded like he should be. I'll just say I'm proud of him. Because at the end of the day it's grown man football and he showed that.‚Äù

Panthers coach Dave Canales greeted Ransom on the sideline with a huge hug after interception, and smiled as he spoke about the rookie after the game.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a great story,‚Äù Canales said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fantastic and it‚Äôs just about belief and having confidence in our guys to be able to be studs about the things we need to work on and be studs about the different decisions that come up. I love that for Lathan ‚Äî for him to be able to make the winning play, the biggest play of the game for us.‚Äù

The Panthers will need more big plays from Ransom and other young players if they hope to dethrone the Buccaneers, who have won the last four NFC South titles.

Carolina can clinch the division with a win next week against Seattle and a Tampa Bay loss to Miami. But if the Bucs win, it will come down to a rematch in Week 18 for the division title.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve learned a bunch throughout the season, especially from that first game,‚Äù Ransom said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to learn. It‚Äôs a learning process. You‚Äôre playing with the best of the best. I learn more and more every game and I try to take those teachings into the next game.‚Äù

AP NFL: https://apnews.com/hub/nfl

title: NFL playoff picture: What Texans‚Äô win over Raiders means for AFC standings in Week 16
description: The Texans face the Raiders in Houston on Sunday. We break down what the game means for the NFL playoff picture in Week 16.
fullText:
Game result: The Texans beat the Raiders, 23-21, in Week 16. Houston improves to 10-5 on the year and stays at the No. 7 seed in the AFC Playoff picture. Houston remains a game behind the Jacksonville Jaguars in the AFC South, who moved to 11-4 with their win over the Denver Broncos on Week 16.

The Houston Texans are closing in on a playoff berth, but it will be at least another week before they will have a clinching scenario. The Texans host the Las Vegas Raiders in Week 16 and this is a game they absolutely cannot lose.

The Texans are 9-5 and have won six straight in a streak that has included wins over the Jaguars, Bills, Colts, and Chiefs. They beat the Cardinals 40-20 last week. The Texans face a Raiders squad that is 2-12 and has lost eight straight games. Last week, the Raiders were thumped by the Eagles 31-0 in Philly.

Houston is a 14.5-point favorite, which is the biggest spread of Week 16.

The Texans are in second place in the division sitting one game back of the Jaguars. Houston and Jacksonville split their season series and the Texans have a half game lead for the divisional tiebreaker (4-1 vs. 3-1). The Jaguars are traveling to face the Broncos this weekend, so if they lose that but win their two remaining games, the tiebreaker would go to record in common games.

Meanwhile, the Colts sit a game back of the Texans and still has one game left with them. Houston won the first game in Week 13. The Colts need to see the Texans lose in Week 16 or 17 to create a situation in which the Colts can finish ahead of them.

The Texans are in seventh place and hold the final wild card spot ahead of the 8-6 Colts and 7-7 Ravens. If the Texans win and the Colts lose, Houston would have a wild card clinching scenario in Week 17 when they travel to face the Chargers. The Texans enter Week 16 with a 98% chance of making the playoffs at The Athletic‚Äôs playoff simulator. Houston has a 58% chance of claiming a wild card berth and a 40% chance of winning the division.

The Raiders are a common opponent for the Texans and Jaguars. There is a very real chance the Texans and Jaguars finish tied and it common opponents. They are also a common opponent with the Chargers, but Houston and LA will have a head-to-head tiebreaker sorted out when they meet in Week 17.

title: Jason Pierre-Paul is back with Bucs so nice guys don‚Äôt finish last
description: Jason Pierre-Paul will be 37 on New Year‚Äôs Day, hasn‚Äôt played in an NFL game in two years or produced more than three sacks in any season since helping the Bucs win Super Bowl 55 following the 2020 season. When Tampa Bay signed him to its practice squad on Dec.
fullText:
Jason Pierre-Paul will be 37 on New Year‚Äôs Day, hasn‚Äôt played in an NFL game in two years or produced more than three sacks in any season since helping the Bucs win Super Bowl 55 following the 2020 season.

When Tampa Bay signed him to its practice squad on Dec. 9, it wasn‚Äôt just to put pressure on opposing quarterbacks. The team felt it could use him to put heat on some of its own players on defense.

Buy FIRE THE CANNONS: 50 Years of Tampa Bay Buccaneers Football

The Bucs didn‚Äôt just need an edge rusher. They needed an edge, someone whose passion might boil over into an opponent‚Äôs penalty. A teammate they would watch with a side-eye, never fully sure what he might do next. A player who made opponents uncomfortable and injected an attitude the locker room couldn‚Äôt manufacture.

In addition to an overall lack of consistent pressure from their defensive line and outside linebacker positions, the Bucs lack someone teammates are afraid to let down.

Think about the best Bucs teams from the past. The Super Bowl 37 champions were stuffed with those kinds of players on defense. Warren Sapp. Even safety John Lynch, who is about as even-tempered off the field as anyone you will ever meet, was borderline maniacal between the lines. He knocked his brother-in-law (Bears tight end John Allred) out cold in a 1997 game at Soldier Field.

Hardy Nickerson was that guy when Lynch, Sapp and Derrick Brooks arrived.

It also helps that Pierre-Paul has a resume. He owns 94 ¬Ω career sacks and 21 forced fumbles. Outside linebacker Yaya Diaby leads the Bucs with only six sacks this season.

Less than two weeks after Pierre-Paul was signed to the practice squad, Diaby says he‚Äôs benefited from the two-time Super Bowl champion‚Äôs counsel.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been good so far, man,‚Äù Diaby said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt even lie. He‚Äôs very intentional with what he‚Äôs done and what he sees that we‚Äôve been doing that he can improve upon. Even for me, he‚Äôll come up and say, ‚ÄòThis is what you can do to get off real faster. You could‚Äôve done this or done that.‚Äô

‚ÄúSo, he‚Äôs been real intentional in trying to share whatever he can. Even (Wednesday), he was telling me, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know everything. But what I do know, I can help you with that.‚Äù

On Saturday, Pierre-Paul was elevated from the practice squad for Sunday‚Äôs game at Carolina. Head coach Todd Bowles had said earlier in the week that Pierre-Paul was ‚Äúin play‚Äù for the NFC South showdown, even with no players forced to miss the game due to injury.

‚ÄúI think he‚Äôs coming in and getting back acclimated systematically in some of the things we‚Äôre asking him to do,‚Äù defensive pass game coordinator George Edwards. ‚ÄúBut I think he‚Äôs been very attentive. It‚Äôs bought into calling some of the plays he‚Äôs done in the past. He‚Äôs here working hard, so we‚Äôll see how it goes. You never know when your number is called to be in those situations.‚Äù

Pierre-Paul‚Äôs energy and passion for the game is infectious, Diaby said.

‚ÄúHe loves it, and he‚Äôs still got some juice,‚Äù Diaby said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs still got some juice.‚Äù

There‚Äôs been far too many miscommunications on the Bucs defense this season. Much of it is on the players. Some of it is opponents going fast to prevent an array of blitzes and coverages to be communicated before the snap.

It‚Äôs one of the reasons why there have been so many missed assignments, a player out of position here or there because the communication breaks down.

Bowles always has been known for the complexity of his defense and the ability to disguise an array of blitzes. But those take time to communicate.

Consequently, opponents are getting to or staying on the ball quickly between snaps.

‚ÄúOn third down, they speed it up some,‚Äù Bowles said. ‚ÄúWe expect that. We‚Äôve been getting that for the last two years. We have to have calls ready. We understand that, and we do have calls ready. We expect to get sped up some.‚Äù

The Bucs and Panthers are both 5-1 in games decided by three points or less this season.

What makes them able to execute in pressure situations?

‚Äúit‚Äôs just playing smart football,‚Äù Bowles said. ‚ÄùWe have to play smart football, and you can‚Äôt beat yourselves and you‚Äôve got to execute.‚Äù

Every weekday, tune into our Sports Day Tampa Bay podcast to hear reporter Rick Stroud break down the biggest stories in Tampa Bay sports.

Never miss out on the latest with your favorite Tampa Bay sports teams. Follow our coverage on X and Facebook.

title: Browns vs. Bills radio coverage: Station, channel, streaming to listen live to NFL Week 16 game broadcast
description: Buffalo is closing in on a playoff spot.
fullText:
Browns vs. Bills radio coverage: Station, channel, streaming to listen live to NFL Week 16 game broadcast originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Buffalo Bills‚Äô dramatic Week 15 victory over the New England Patriots was far more than a simple rivalry win; it was a season-saving, division-defining statement.

Trailing 21-0 in the first half at Gillette Stadium, quarterback Josh Allen led the Bills on a historic comeback, scoring five consecutive touchdowns to erase the deficit and secure the thrilling 35-31 win. The victory was crucial, as it prevented the Patriots from clinching the AFC East title on their home turf and kept Buffalo's own slim division hopes mathematically alive heading into the final three weeks of the season.

More importantly for their immediate postseason aspirations, that massive win cemented the Bills (10-4) as the leading Wild Card contender in the highly competitive AFC playoff picture. Currently holding the No. 6 seed, Buffalo‚Äôs favorable tiebreakers give them a strong foothold as they enter a demanding closing schedule. With the Los Angeles Chargers and Houston Texans nipping at their heels, maintaining momentum is essential to avoid being dragged back into the desperate fight for the final playoff spots.

That urgency brings the Bills to Cleveland this Sunday for a pivotal matchup against the Browns (3-11). While Cleveland has struggled through a disappointing season, their defense ‚Äîled by the perennial Defensive Player of the Year candidate Myles Garrett ‚Äîremains highly disruptive. The quarterback battle is one to watch: Shedeur Sanders will make his fifth NFL start against the reigning MVP in Josh Allen.

Ultimately, Sunday's clash at Huntington Bank Field is an absolute "must-win" for Buffalo. Having survived the biggest challenge of their season by battling back against the Patriots, the Bills cannot afford a letdown against a struggling opponent if they want to secure their spot in the postseason for a seventh straight year. A win would keep the pressure squarely on New England in the AFC East race and put Buffalo on the very brink of officially punching their ticket as the top team in the AFC Wild Card standings.

title: Patriots playoff picture: Rooting guide for Week 16 games around NFL
description: Who Patriots fans should be rooting for in Week 16 of the 2025 NFL season.
fullText:
The New England Patriots will try to get back into the win column this week versus the Baltimore Ravens. Naturally, all of our attention is on that particular Sunday night matchup. That said, some of the other 15 games around the NFL this week are also worth keeping a close eye on.

With that said, welcome to this week‚Äôs Patriots rooting guide.

As a disclaimer, we are looking at games through two primary lenses: New England‚Äôs chances of winning the division ‚Äî which they cannot do this week ‚Äî as well as earning the No. 1 seed in the AFC. Naturally and given the tiebreaker situation, not every game will be equally important even if it involves common opponents or other teams in the conference or division.

The Patriots were entering the weekend with a 73% chance of winning the division, according to The Athletic, and are 99+% favorite to make the playoffs (they actually can punch their ticket on Sunday). Their odds for the No. 1 seed are not nearly as good and a mere 10% at the moment.

Tampa Bay Buccaneers (7-7) at Carolina Panthers (7-7): Go good game! Division supremacy on the line, but the Patriots do not care who will win this one. | FOX

Buffalo Bills (10-4) at Cleveland Browns (3-11): Go Browns! The Patriots won‚Äôt lock up the division this week either way, but Buffalo dropping this one would give them more wiggle room: if the Bills lose and they beat the Ravens, the Patriots would be up two games with two weeks to go. | CBS

Los Angeles Chargers (10-4) at Dallas Cowboys (6-7-1): Go Cowboys! The Chargers entering the competition for the No. 1 seed in the AFC is unlikely but not entirely impossible. This is merely based on keeping another competitor away from the race for the first-round bye in the conference. | FOX

Cincinnati Bengals (4-10) at Miami Dolphins (6-8): Go Dolphins! Miami is out of the playoffs, so all wins do over the last three weeks is further weaken the team‚Äôs draft position. | CBS

New York Jets (3-11) at New Orleans Saints (4-10): Go Jets! This is the same we talked about with the Dolphins, namely that the Jets adding some more wins down the stretch would end up hurting their draft stock. | CBS

Minnesota Vikings (6-8) at New York Giants (2-12): Go good game! This all-NFC matchup has no impact on the Patriots. | FOX

Kansas City Chiefs (6-8) at Tennessee Titans (2-12): Go Titans! The more games the Chiefs end up losing, the better for New England: they own a Kansas City sixth-rounder next year courtesy of the Joshua Uche trade. The worse their record, the better positioned the pick. | CBS

Atlanta Falcons (5-9) at Arizona Cardinals (3-11): Go good game! Nothing to see here, really. | FOX

Jacksonville Jaguars (10-4) at Denver Broncos (12-2): Go Jaguars! This is a big one. If the Patriots want to take over the No. 1 seed in the AFC, they will need Denver to start losing some games. This one against the red hot Jaguars is a realistic candidate. | FOX

Pittsburgh Steelers (8-6) at Detroit Lions (8-6): Go Lions! The Steelers missing out on the playoffs would be good news for the Patriots and the sixth-round draft pick they received as part of the Kyle Dugger trade. Obviously, in an ideal scenario, Pittsburgh would still be ahead of the Ravens after Week 16, but a loss here would keep the chances intact of Baltimore eventually leap-frogging their division rivals and pushing them out of postseason contention. | CBS

Las Vegas Raiders (2-12) at Houston Texans (9-5): Go good game! Even though this is a game between two AFC teams, including one competing for a playoff spot, the game has no real impact on New England. | CBS

San Francisco 49ers (10-4) at Indianapolis Colts (8-6): Go Colts! We end the week with a focus on draft positioning. In the unlikely case the 49ers drop out of the playoff picture in the NFC, the Patriots would benefit: the conditional sixth-round pick acquired in the Keion White trade would be better positioned in that case. | ESPN

The following games have taken place earlier in the week:

Los Angeles Rams (11-3) at Seattle Seahawks (11-3): Go good game! Given the stakes, this is one of the top Thursday night games in recent memories. And while it has no impact on the Patriots, it should be a fun watch nonetheless. | LA 37, SEA 38 (OT)

Philadelphia Eagles (9-5) at Washington Commanders (4-10): Go good game! A no-impact game from a Patriots perspective. | PHI 29, WAS 18

Green Bay Packers (9-4-1) at Chicago Bears (10-4): Go Packers! While the game won‚Äôt change New England‚Äôs playoff outlook, it could end up impacting the draft. The Patriots, after all, own the Bears‚Äô fourth-round pick sent to them by the Chiefs as part of an in-draft trade last year. | GB 16, CHI 22 (OT)

This article also serves as an open thread for this week‚Äôs games. Please head down to the comment section to discuss and share your thoughts on the games as they unfold.

title: Best NFL players ever on the worst teams: Myles Garrett, Calvin Johnson and the 16 most wasted talents in history
description: These 16 NFL players are among football's all-time greats, but their teams were anything but.
fullText:
Best NFL players ever on the worst teams: Myles Garrett, Calvin Johnson and the 16 most wasted talents in history originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Cleveland edge rusher Myles Garrett is on the edge of making NFL history.

Garrett ‚Äì who has 21.5 sacks ‚Äì can tie the NFL single-season sack record held by former Giants star Michael Strahan and Steelers edge rusher T.J Watt with his next sack. Garrett, of course, is playing for the Browns ‚Äì who have been eliminated from the AFC playoff race.

That's going to beg the question: Is Garrett the best player on the worst team in NFL history? We're not just talking about this year. We're talking for the entirety of their career.

Sporting News identified 16 NFL stars ‚Äì including eight Pro Football Hall of Fame players ‚Äì who fit that description. We ranked those players based on four categories, including worst team winning percentage, playoff appearances (fewest scored higher), Pro Bowl selections (highest to lowest) and NFL MVP or AP Defensive Player of the Year Awards. In the event of a tie, the player whose teams had a lower winning percentage wen

This balances the great player vs. how good, or in this case bad, their team was.

Garrett is in the top 10 along with another active edge rusher in the NFL. Who else made the list? A look at the 16 best NFL players on the worst teams.

MORE:Tracking Myles Garrett's NFL single-season sacks record chase

Teams: Saints (1999-2001), Dolphins (2002-03, 2005, 2007-10), Ravens (2011)

Williams ‚Äì who rushed for 10,009 yards ‚Äì had a rough start in New Orleans. He played for seven different head coaches ‚Äì ranging from Mike Ditka to Nick Saban ‚Äì retired for a year and was suspended for another. Williams played on a 3-13 team in New Orleans and a 1-15 team in Miami.

Teams: Buccaneers (1987-92), Browns (1993-95), Ravens (1996-97), Jets (1998-2003, 2005), Cowboys (2004), Patriots (2006), Panthers (2007)

Team playoff record: 4‚Äì3 (2-3 as a starter)

The Buccaneers were 28-67 in six seasons after selecting Testaverde with the No. 1 pick in the 1987 NFL Draft. Testaverde was 23-25 in three seasons with Bill Belichick in Cleveland. He spent two seasons in Baltimore before the best stretch of his career with the Jets and made a start in the 1998 AFC championship game against Denver. Testaverde reunited with Bill Parcells in Dallas and Belichick in New England late in his career. He finished with a 90-123-1 record as a starter with 46,233 yards, which ranks 18th on the all-time list.

Teams: Bengals (1996-2007), Ravens (2008)

Anderson ‚Äì a four-time Pro Bowl selection ‚Äì played for four different coaches during the late 1990s and early 2000s "Bungles" era, and he played on just one winning team in 12 seasons with the franchise. Anderson played in one playoff game ‚Äì a heart-breaking 31-17 loss to the Steelers in the AFC Wild Card round. Anderson did reach the AFC championship game with rival Balti

Teams: Colts (1983-89), Falcons (1990-93), Vikings (1994-95)

Hinton ‚Äì a seven-time Pro Bowl selection ‚Äì was the player the Colts got in the John Elway trade. Hinton was a mainstay at tackle, but the Colts had four straight losing seasons after his arrival. Hinton played in four playoff games in his career, which also had stints with the Falcons and Vikings. He probably deserves more Pro Football Hall of Fame consideration.

Sanders ‚Äì who ranks fourth all time in NFL history with 15,269 yards ‚Äì played on decent teams. Detroit had a winning record in five of his 10 seasons and made the NFC championship game in 1991. Sanders abruptly retired in 1998 after the Lions finished 5-11 in 1998. Sanders' highlight reel has been passed down a few generations ‚Äì but he never played in a Super Bowl.

Teams: Rams (2004-12), Falcons (2013-14), Patriots (2015)

Jackson played on some miserable teams in St. Louis. The Rams averaged three wins per season from 2007-11 ‚Äì a stretch in which Jackson had five straight 1,000-yard seasons. He finished his career with 11,438 rushing yards, and one of his two career playoff victories was in an abbreviated final season with the Patriots in 2015.

Sayers had a brief-but-brilliant career with the Bears, which was cut short by injuries. Sayers played for George Halas for four seasons ‚Äì a stretch where Chicago compiled a 28-25-3 record. He led the NFL in rushing with 236 carries for 1,032 yards and eight TDs in 1969, a season in which the Bears finished 1-13.

Teams: Saints (1993-2001); Chiefs (2002-05)

Roaf was a dominant tackle in the NFL for the Saints ‚Äì and he played for three head coaches in Jim Mora, Mike Ditka and Jim Haslett. New Orleans won one playoff game ‚Äì a 34-24 victory against St. Louis in the NFC Wild Card round ‚Äì on Dec. 30, 2000. He played four seasons with Kansas City ‚Äì including two winning teams ‚Äì to end his career.

Teams: Jaguars (2006-13), Raiders (2014)

Jones-Drew helped Jacksonville reach the AFC divisional playoffs in his second season, but it went downhill from there despite a successful career in which he finished with 8,167 rushing yards in nine seasons. MJD played on teams that won an average of three games in his final three seasons between Jacksonville and Oakland.

Stephen R. Sylvanie-Imagn Images

Crosby ‚Äì who has 69.5 career sacks ‚Äì has been with the franchise since the move from Oakland to Las Vegas. He has endured four straight losing seasons with the Raiders and has played for three coaches in each of the last three seasons. Yet Crosby remains on a trajectory that would get him to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

The Browns went 0-16 in Garrett's first season, so it's technically been uphill from there. Garrett has played for the same coach for six seasons in Kevin Stefanski, and the Browns did beat the Steelers 48-37 in the AFC Wild Card round on Jan. 10, 2021. It hasn't been all bad for the former No. 1 pick.

Johnson never played on a team that won a playoff game. Detroit finished 0-16 in his second season, but "Megatron" continued to produce at a ridiculous level. The six-time Pro Bowl selection had 122 catches for a single-season record 1,964 receiving yards in 2012. Detroit had two winning seasons in nine years with Johnson on the field.

Kennedy ‚Äì an eight-time Pro Bowl selection ‚Äì never played on a team that won 10 games or 

You can't think about the Tampa Bay creamsicle jerseys without Selmon, the six-time Pro Bowl selection who dominated at defensive tackle for the Bucs despite some woeful teams. Tampa Bay went 0-14 in Selmon's rookie season, and they lost 10 or more games six times in his nine seasons.

Butkus ‚Äì arguably the most-feared defensive player of his era ‚Äì was on the same teams as Gale Sayers, but the linebacker played two more seasons. Butkus made the Pro Bowl eight times in eight seasons before his final year, in which he played just nine games. He also finished in the top five in the NFL MVP voting twice despite playing for teams that finished with records of 8-8 and 7-9, respectively.

Thomas is the easiest choice here. He was a 10-time Pro Bowl selection in Cleveland despite a cast of revolving door of quarterbacks and coaches through one of the most-unstable periods for any franchise in NFL history. Cleveland went 10-6 in Thomas' first season. The Browns never won more than five games over the next 10 years, and Thomas' final season was the 0-16 year in 2017. Despite that, Thomas remains one of the most-beloved athletes in Cleveland sports history.

title: Cowboys eliminated from NFL playoffs in Week 16 and you can blame the Eagles
description: The Dallas Cowboys have officially been eliminated from playoff contention.
fullText:
The Dallas Cowboys have been eliminated from playoff contention.

You may have felt that this was the case for some time already in a matter of fact sense, but it became official on Saturday night when the Philadelphia Eagles beat the Washington Commanders. Thanks to losses over the last two weeks to the Detroit Lions and Minnesota Vikings the Cowboys left themselves with only one path into the postseason and that was as the hypothetical winner of the NFC East. That will not come to pass as the Eagles have now won it.

Much is always made about how the NFC East has not featured a back-to-back champion since 2003 and 2004 when the Eagles did it themselves. They have put that all to an end by doing it once more and on the subject of streaks the Cowboys now have one going themselves as far as playoff absences are concerned.

Dallas missed the playoffs last year, they were eliminated around the same time as it happened on December 22nd, which means they have missed the postseason for two years in a row for the first time since 2019 and 2020. Then, like now, the Cowboys were in the final year of one head coach (Jason Garrett) and the first of another (Mike McCarthy). It is almost like that is not necessarily a recipe for success.

There is a lot of introspection that is necessary from the Cowboys these days and their current playoff drought is representative of that. We talk often about how this team hasn‚Äôt been the same since they were bounced from the 2023 Wild Card Round and obviously the evidence here speaks for that as well.

We now know conclusively that there are only 3 games left on the season for the Cowboys. We also know that their drought for Super Bowl and/or NFC Championship Game appearances (the drought that Stephen Jones didn‚Äôt understand to exist) will officially grow to 30 years. It is not an approximation or a rounding up.

title: NFL Player Prop Picks: Week 16 Best Bets
description: Rohit Ponnaiya breaks down his favorite Week 16 NFL player props, including Jacoby Brissett and Aaron Rodgers.
fullText:
It's going to be a Blue Christmas for Tua Tagovailoa, who has been benched by the Dolphins. With Miami breaking in a rookie QB, my NFL props are betting on RB De'Von Achane to carry the offense.

See why I'm backing Achane, Jacoby Brissett, and Aaron Rodgers with my favorite NFL player props for Week 16 in the NFL.

Kyler Murray who? Jacoby Brissett gone over his passing yards total in all nine of his starts this season. He has thrown the ball at least 40 times in six straight contests, averaging a whopping 45.7 pass attempts per game over that span.

The Arizona Cardinals have struggled to run the ball and have practically abandoned that part of their offense. They are second in the NFL in passing play percentage (65.4%), with that number ballooning to 72.5% over the last six weeks.

The Cardinals are hosting the Atlanta Falcons on Sunday in a beautiful 76-degree day at State Farm Stadium. That should lead to plenty of throwing from a pair of teams with nothing to play for except pride.

With the Miami Dolphins starting seventh-round rookie Quinn Ewers at QB expect them to lean on their rushing attack against a piss-poor Bengals run defense. Cincinnati is 30th in the NFL in defensive rush EPA and allows a league-high 157.9 rushing yards per game.

Even if the Bengals sell out to stop the run, they won't be able to contain Achane. They allow 5.0 yards per carry when stacking the box, and De'Von Achane averages 5.8 yards per attempt when running against a stacked box.

Achane is coming off a game where he was limited to 60 yards on 12 carries due to a negative game script.¬†However, he had rushed for more than 90 yards in his previous four contests, averaging 130.0 rushing yards per game over that span.

Aaron Rodgers is coming off back-to-back contests where he completed 23 passes in wins against the Dolphins and Ravens. The four-time MVP is proving that he still has something left in the tank, and he faces a struggling Detroit Lions pass defense in Week 16.

The Lions are 25th in the league in dropback EPA since Week 9. Their injury-depleted secondary is getting picked apart with Detroit allowing 24.3 completions per game over the last three contests.

With the Lions 7-point faves on Sunday, expect a negative game script for the Pittsburgh Steelers with plenty of passing. Rodgers has completed more than 20.5 passes in six of his last nine games and should eclipse that number again.

After a red-hot start to the season, Jacksonville Jaguars running back Travis Etienne Jr. has cooled off. Etienne has logged fewer than 60 rushing yards in six of his last 10 games and is averaging just 3.8 yards per carry over that span.

He was held to fewer than 35 rushing yards and less than 3.0 ypa in two of his last three games. What's especially concerning about those numbers is that they came with a positive game script against terrible Titans and Jets defenses.

He'll have a much tougher time in Week 16 against a Denver stop unit that allows the second-fewest rushing yards per game (90.9) on 3.9 yards per carry. Etienne is at his best on outside zone runs, where he averages 6.9 yards per rush. However, the Broncos allow just 3.3 yards per rush on outside zone attempts.

New Orleans Saints wideout Chris Olave reeled in six catches for 85 yards last week. He has logged at least 62 receiving yards in six of his last nine games, and he's finally getting good quarterback play with Tyler Shough under center.

Olave gets a mouth-watering matchup this week at home against the New York Jets, who traded away top corner Sauce Gardner at the deadline. The Jets are 31st in the league in defensive dropback EPA while ranking 28th in DVOA against No. 1 WRs.

Olave has been the Saints' only reliable pass catcher after they traded Rashid Shaheed and Brandin Cooks, so expect him to get fed the ball. This is a five-star play according to EV Analytics, which is projecting 71.57 yards for Olave.

Brissett o37.5 pass attempts (-120)

Rodgers o20.5 completions (-138)

Etienne u60.5 rush yards (-114)

Olave o61.5 receiving yards (-114)

My NFL weekly props column is 39-31 this season for +3.86 units.

title: Cardinals Trey McBride sets two NFL records
description: Talented tight end has a season full of league records
fullText:
This 2025 NFL season hasn‚Äôt been what was expected from the Arizona Cardinals. In a division full of some of the league‚Äôs best ballclubs, the Cardinals aren‚Äôt one of them.

But there are silver linings. And with some, you don‚Äôt have to look too hard. Arizona tight end Trey McBride might be this year‚Äôs brightest star on the roster. He has already set one league record several weeks ago, and now this past weekend, he set two more.

In the Cardinals‚Äô 40-20 loss to the Houston Texans this past Sunday, McBride had 12 receptions for 134 yards and scored two touchdowns to lead all pass catchers.

Among the flow of the game, McBride set two records: 1) ‚ÄúMost consecutive games by a tight end with five or more catches,‚Äù and 2) ‚ÄúFirst tight end in NFL history to have 100 catches or 

With the first record, McBride now has 16 consecutive games, which broke the record of 15 held by Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs in 2018.

Last year, McBride caught 111 passes for 1,146 yards. He now has 105 passes for 1,071 this season with three games remaining.

McBride can now set his sights on the NFL record for ‚ÄúMost receptions by a tight end in a single season.‚Äù The record is 116 catches set by former Cardinal Zack Ertz in 2018 while he was playing for the Philadelphia Eagles. Needing an even dozen in three games shouldn‚Äôt be an issue for McBride.

He is currently ranked #1 in receptions in the league, #2 in targets, #3 in touchdowns, #4 in first down conversions, #6 in total yards gained, and #25 in pass completions of 20+ yards.

Two weeks ago, McBride broke the NFL record for the ‚ÄúMost receptions by a tight end in his first four seasons in the league.‚Äù The old record was set by tight end Jimmy Graham, who had 3,863 yards on 301 receptions. Against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Week 13, McBride led all receivers with eight catches for 82 yards and a touchdown, and finished with 309 career receptions. He has since added to that total.
